posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6457165
Your pressure sensitivity isn't working for some reason. If you can, select a pen/brush and right next to it's size in the tool property box, there's another button. It may be a box with a slash through it if none of it's settings are on. Try clicking this and turning on pen pressure.

If that's not working it may be your tablet and you'll have to look into it's settings. And if you don't have a tablet I don't think you can even have pressure sensitivity.

posts.com:
I think i hit limit growth. I cant grow past around 2.2k followers (on twitter)

I post frequently and get around 600 likes on a good day but followers are going up very slowly.

Should i draw for a different audience? More original content? Or should i just try to improve my skills?

I also post comics but those don't do very well in terms of numbers despite getting lots of positive comments and stuff.

How did you guys break through the limit? Is the solution really just to keep drawing?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434940
I think 600 likes for 2k is a very good amount. Theres people with 10k who get less than that.
The usual tips are the same as always, drawing OCs from larger users, try nsfw, fotm, keep posting a lot and such. You are already improving as you keep drawing and posting new content, your followers notice that.

I think the luck factor is very important. Being in the right spot at the right time. How do RTs from big accounts work for you? Do they get lots of likes/follows? If thats so, aim for that.

Me personally cant grow by my own anymore as Im shadowbanned. I draw nsfw, not hardcore stuff though, just nudes. Everytime I post something new, my tweet gets hidden for at least 12 hours. It isnt showing in the search option, not by keywords, neither tags. I rely just on my own followers and luck. And even my own followers dont see my posts most of the time. I have 3k, but only getting 30 likes or so because of this. The moment another account RTs me, I can reach 3k likes. Thats really awful and discouraging.

I wish there were other places for promote yourself instead of depending 100% on that.

I'm stuck at 230 or so but I only do original stuff mostly. Try doing fanart or drawing bigger account OCs. The only reason I am at 230 and not 30 is because I did art for someone's OC I like and they RT'd it. But do it only if you like their art otherwise it's scummy imo.

Also meme shit does very well, if you can take an existing meme and put a creative spin on it or make it relatable artist shit then those tend to do very well. But then you're left with an audience that only followed for more memes and dont really care about your original art. So it depends on what sort of account you have and what you want to post.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6451767
I dont remember right now in previous versions, but you can press 'P' as a hotkey for the color picker

>>6451775
When Im first sketching a scene it looks kinda similar, its my style. But its been months since my last big draw. Think that I sculpt with my pen in ZBrush, so Im basically drawing in 3D, rotating 360º my figures and adjusting them on every angle, they need to look fine.

Creating 3D scenes instead of 2D, allows me to do many other things, like rotating over the scene, animating, scaling specific parts, changing the pose or working with cloth/fluid physics.

But the main reason for using them in interactive scenes inside Unreal is for example changing their clothes with particle effects, different hairstyles, or anything you can imagine inside a videogame.
Im still polishing my scenes but Im planning to make them downloadable with small minigames and such

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6448467
Rushed this one out, sorry, but essentially it boils down to two things, anon. Contrast, and grouping. Your values/shadows essentially are the result of form and light. Right now you're adding unnecessary detail in areas that should be low detail, like the belly. You're leaving small light spots that attract our attention where it shouldn't be (if the tummy should be the highlight you'd need a different composition.)

When you think about values and light you should think of the painting as a whole. Unless it's concept art, a middle range value lile the one you picked for your painting is a pretty bad place to start, because already the whole composition is pretty much in the same value range. Especially early you shouldn't be afraid of really pushing the value range, somdare to go much darker and much lighter.

Keep your light sourse in mind. And what the light itself /is/. Different types of light will cause different shadows to be created. Harsh sunlight, for example, causes fairly dark but warm coloured shadows and might cause light to bounce off large surfaces. So a chin, which is pointing downwards but juts out might cast a lighter shadow than the nect area, as light is being reflected off of the ground. This is why thinking of form is also very important.

Originally I wanted like a mid forwards jump with his upper body doing a clockwise twisting motion. I changed it to a peak jump up kinda pose with the twisting still because I couldn't make the original work with the 5:4 canvas. I guess in changing the cape too, I kinda lost the twisting motion with it. Maybe I can modify it to imply a bit more the pulling in the shoulder due to the twisting motion. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6455701

I post in random discord servers, ones not related to art at all. The smaller and more social the better. I use telegram too. Engage as much as possible and try and get people to interact with you as a person first as the highest priority and then as an artist as a close second.

My feeling is if you put your shit in the kind of places where people can find furry art, they're probably already internet literate and discerning about their tastes and art standards, so if they're presented with the cost of your art compared to someone else's which is identical but cheaper they're 95% gonna choose the cheaper option, the other 5 % are going to choose you only if there's something really unique about your product. The internet is really fucking wide and anyone who's been there knows nothing is unique there.

My goal was to collect ten geese that shit out gold eggs. The best I ever got was one patron, I got real depressed drawing cocks for them hours and hours each day. But if you go the internet version of door knocking instead of the flyer drop, you have a better chance of finding patrons who will pay you what they think you're worth, not what you lowball.

Best I was turning was a small handful of 100 USD dollars per commish, but they each took me probs a months and a half to complete, not because they were hard, but because I got so depressed with it and procrastinated really hard.

>>6449931
Memory drawing: Look at the image, put the image away, draw it from memory. It's a brutal but effective way of learning, I estimate you'll see improvement at 5x speed. I wouldn't recommend it as a beginner necessarily, since you first gotta be able to draw a passable figure first. The memory thing is just forcing you to recall from your visual library more effectively.

As a beginner, just copy Bridgman, and do your life drawing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6450083
>>6450221
Hi Bridgman-san, you're doing fine, I've been posting along with you in /msg/ this past year. Attached is a page from when I was in the feet section, the memory drawing and corrections are both there, so it's great we both had the idea of correcting the drawing after the fact. The chapter I struggled the most on was the beginning chapter, with all the full figures, but once you start getting into the body parts it goes a lot quicker.

My end goal was to get my drawing EXACTLY like how Bridgman had it, but of course I often fell short. In the beginning, I would stare at the drawing for 15-20 minutes, drawing it in my head over and over again, then I would bang out the sketch really quickly, to not lose any information. When I was doing the full figures in the first chapter, I could only do 1-2 drawings at a time before my brain went caput, but it really does get a lot easier after that.

My one criticism of your process is to use pencil, and then ink on top. imo it's important to give yourself the room to make mistakes. Even all my ballpoint pen sketches I did from manga in /msg/, I used pencil underneath.

About me taking only 1 month to go through Bridgman versus how long you've been doing it, I just chalk that up to the fact that I already had several years of drawing experience before doing Bridgman, so I could do my studies very quickly, and i did it for 8 hours a day, like a maniac. For you, don't worry about how long you're taking, 1-2 hrs a day is plenty to progress. I think you're doing it right, I might've rushed Bridgman, to my own detriment.

Anyways, do your 30 mins of gestures, and your Bridgman, and you'll do fine. However, Bridgman isn't the end, even after finishing it I still feel inadequate. You really will have to study for the rest of your life.

>>6453917
the head section isn't bad, you have to know what his drawings are shorthand for. drawing as many heads in cubes as you can showing the planes is tremendous practice for drawing in perspective. he would commonly recommend that as a warmup for that at the art students league.

a lot of the diagrams are modeled after how master painters in the 1800s and before would think about anatomy. the only one i don't care for in your picture is the child but that's making a point of what all the bumps are that cause plane changes on a face which you might not recognize as being indicative of the anatomy.

>>6436845
This isn't a comment I got but these 2 characters I've been fleshing out for a comic for years, ended up getting "copied" by 2 big name cartoon shows like 4 years after I imagined them myself. It pissed me off at first, but I didn't let it get to me. I resolved instead to adjust my characters and their narrative world in a way that mogs those cartoons(in my opinion,) and makes my characters even more distinctly my own. I'll never get famous from it and retards might still try to compare my characters (which came first) to the characters from the cartoons, or even some unpredictable media I've never heard of. But I'll never doubt myself about it and that's what matters. My creations have a life of their own, it's my job to convince people to see them as distinct, and hell it might even be fun to lean into some of the comparisons for laughs. If you aren't fighting tooth and nail to carve out your own identity through your creations you're just too weak.

lol i'm a person who says this sometimes (paired with other advice). i don't say "looks like shit" because it's just not a useful citicism
it doesn't tell the other person what they did wrong or how to improve on the picture or which skill they should focus on
furthermore, it's not like putting a lot of effort into a shitty image has never happened to me - i assume the other person already knows their work looks "bad somehow" but doesn't know how to fix it, and that in that state it's pretty easy to fall into the trap of thinking all the time you put into something was a total waste and a sign that you have hit a "wall" and will never improve.
so, in combination with other suggested practical solutions, it's just a reminder that time invested into practice isn't useless, at a time when it is easy to think that way, and have that mentality block your growth.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6456218
I had a similar issue and it might sound retarded but try going the exact opposite direction and take some time aside to do whatever you think would be the most miserable, unfun exercise. For me that was copying a Bargue plate. By the end of it you won't have burst into flames and even if it takes way longer than it should've or looks horrible it's not the end of the world and you'll have gotten something out of the experience.
After doing that I became progressively more ok with the idea of doing studies even though I used to be super averse to the very idea of drawing copies since you're going through all that trouble just to reproduce something that's already there. I understood the value theoretically but had no fucking patience to subject myself to it. Sitting down to study and analyze a picture can actually end up being really fun, specially if it's an artist you like. To me this was unthinkable because the only way I had fun before was making shit up and tossing the drawing as soon as I got bored.
Just pick one thing and stick with it, the more you do it the more used you'll get to it. For me, at least, the problem was that I was too used to drawing mindlessly as recreation so studying felt unnatural and scary. It's just a matter of getting used to something unfamiliar.
Again I know it's retardedly simple but I think it's the most reliable solution. Just be consistent with it and eventually the aversion will be gone. You'll always have plenty of time to draw your own stuff for fun, and it'll expand your options.

posts.sub: Been thinking of tracing AI results.
posts.com:
Starting to think making a crappy sketch, drawing with AI and then tracing it by hand and polish with low noise value to be a worthwhile method.

Not making an anti AI or smug AI dabs on /beg/ losers.

Thinking this method can save me easily 50% of my mental effort when doing a piece.

Because tracing something and then just fixing details by hand when tracing is much more easier mentally than doing the whole process of anatomy and other checks when you the whole box maniqui and perspective and compositional check and other shit.

Also, photobashing results from diferent AI results into a single piece to provide some solid results, much better than what I initially hoped.

I don't mean I lack skills, just that mentally is much easier to trace and fix than do the whole drawing from scratch.

58 was my peak realism oil painting, which I did in high school, at age 15 of all things (thanks picasso)

59 was my first sense of mental distress when i had entered college not fully prepared or committed to being a doctor.

81-82 were figure studies from life for the one semester i was an art major

04 -05 end up dropping acid and failing out of college as a result of going literally insane

In my insanity I felt as if at one moment I literally encountered a divine force, which only made sense to me to be jesus christ, moving effortlessly through my reality, tearing through it like paper

though I am an atheist originally, i was spiritual at this point , though now and then i have moments of faith in Yeshua rising from the dead.
this spawns artworks 07,08,84,85,90, 11

then i did a lot of DXM and basically accepted that made me trans more or less, except just in my sexuality of drawing women, i liked to imagine myself as them. This never manifested outside of drawing though, unless i took adderall which made me sexual enough to put on womens clothes.

I don't think I am really a woman on the inside though, its just fun to fap to. I've held pretty much heteronormative relationships otherwise.

I'm an odd blend of crazy jesus sex magic

I have come to the conclusion that if you are past the age of 26, there is no point in getting into art. You have missed the boat. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The pic says it all,but I will interpret it.

The picture is a panel from the storyboards of another storyline that I had to abandon. The guy getting yelled at is a young magician who is being hunted by the archmage who once imprisoned him until the archmage's granddaughter helped him escape. And moments later he watched her get devoured whole by a demon sent to retrieve him. And for the past few years, this fugitive has been befriended by other girls,only to watch them meet similar terrible ends. Consequently, he wants to remain friendless, because his soul cannot take another senseless death brought about by his pursuit.

The girl doing the screaming is the latest girl to stumble into his life,and she wants to stand by him,knowing his past and troubles. In the previous panels,they walked together and he unburdened himself with a soliloquy about how he wishes he wouldn't have anyone care for him, because he knows too well what happens to those who do. Her response?

She tackles him. And tells him he doesn't get that choice. The last panel is her hugging him fiercely, and a wall of words repeats "You don't get a choice" frames the panel. And he struggles with his own tears,knowing he will undoubtedly doom another innocent soul.

I am struggling with my own tears writing about this. Why? I know these people, and everything about them. I watch their lives unfold under my pen,and cheer and grieve with them. Their stories are important to me, and I have to get them on paper, so they can live on after me,and maybe change their world, and mine as well. And it's why I say loudly, repeatedly, and evangelically, Follow Your Story. A random sketch of a demon head led to a sprawling mystery about a castle in a snowglobe, and after 180 strips over the decade, was just hurrying to the conclusion. You don't know where the story goes until you actually put it on paper, and even if I won't live to see it reach other media, I will put it down. I have no choice.

>>6451772
Books and poetry are indeed art. Prompts are not. Prompts are more fundamental. The same prompt might generate many types of arts.

It's like I wanted to copyright blue + yellow color combination. Many arts can be made with those 2 colors. Same with music. You're free to pick any scale and any of the notes to create your art with any instrument. Just because you use 3 chords from the available pool of options, does not give you rights to the chords itself.

You can make a point of owning the final art of a prompt, the ones you generate with it. But the prompt itself is not art, it does not matter how complex it is. It is a tool that anyone can use, and it can generate art for them that are different from yours.

>>6456847
lol. Except that -unlike when choosing a partner- when drawing you actually need to be careful with anatomical features, since you're the one creating them.

Pointy elbows and knees in drawing (when not a part of a style that makes use of pointy shapes) is an easy way to tell the artist has little anatomical background. The olecranon process of the ulna is rounded, and connects directly to the tendon of the triceps; making it roundish. The kneecap is surrounded by tendons from the quads, and the condyles of the femur and the top of the tibia are also part of what you see when a knee is bent.

In other words... you need to study

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6456780
>Yes, passion, soul and spirit are just made up concepts to try to attack AI art because it so obviously looks good to the human eye.
There's more to art than just looking good to the human eye. That's why the term "eye candy" is derogatory in art, it means superficial.
'Soul' deconstructed is simply the human element. The more the human element is taken out of art, the less 'soul' it has. It's why jazz and blues has more soul than the latest auto-tuned pop song. It's why Ray Harryhausen's stop motion has more soul than shitty CGI effects. It's why great literature has more soul than formulaic YA novels.
Substance is another way to look at. And apple might be shiny but have nothing inside.

VR chat did not exist when I was actively building in Second Life, from 2006-11. People could make real cash building stuff in it. I sold animated paintings and other strange things, but the lure was the creative outlet for me. You conjure basic shapes out of the air,morph them,link them up into larger objects,and insert scripts to make them do various tasks. My paintings were textures of the frames of GIFs laid out in a grid,and the script would display them in order,giving the illusion of animation.

I am part of their official history, in a small way. See the eye in the lower center of the pic? That archway was my contribution to Burning Life 2007,the Burning Man event. Here is a video of it...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6450621
Ok, its different.
I used to draw 2D years ago, I always loved art. I was also working with 3D stuff. But a couple of years ago I really wanted to try sculpting my own characters and trying that route.

3D as other person said adds that extra dimension and, unless you are not going to rotate a single degree your camera, everything can go wrong with just small movement. Do you know how in 2D drawing you are always mirroring the image just in case theres something wrong you didnt see because your mind got used to it?
Well, in 3D you keep rotating the model, zooming in, seeing how that face looks in that angle, from behind, profile, activating the perspective, adjusting the fov...

And thats only the sculpting thing. Then theres the UV, rig, weight painting, texturing (painting), knowledge of many programs (well I dont use Blender), retopo, baking textures, lighting, camera setup, animating and other extra things in Unreal like adding particles, C++ programming, cloth physics, environmental design, props, etc etc.

Here is my latest scene. You'll say:
>why so much work for something you can just draw?
First of all, I love 3D, pushing me over and over, making me proud of my work. The practical/useful part is I'm able to use these sculpts for many other things, like interactive clothes, changing their hairs, lighting/shadows in real time, making some minigames with them or anything you can imagine

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6455988
In my experience, everyone learns differently, which is why it's so hard to give good advice. Also, most artists who've "made it" couldn't tell you exactly how they got there, in perfect sequence, because it tends to be haphazard, with a lot of trial and error. Certain information only helps when you're ready for it, so in two years you might return to something that seems useless now only to have it trigger an epiphany. You can definitely learn observational drawing by following a prescribed method (join an atelier program for the fastest and most assured progress), but there's no fail-proof guide to drawing from imagination and developing an appealing style.

posts.com:
Why You Should Copy Anime:
https://i.imgur.com/zNDsyF0.jpg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kbKqIJcIUCw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dgjx6y6B_G8

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

Recommended Resources:
https://pastebin.com/Yz2scAEc

/mmg/ - Manga Making General:
>>>/ic/mmg

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6443881
>read pen & ink by guptill, it's literally what mangakas study
>take a few pieces of lineart from an artist you like and try to do a study from like where you imitate the style of rendering on a more simplistic object
>do a rough sketch and then try different line techniques on another layer, then try drawing another version w/o the underdrawing
what helped me a lot was taking a month where i only drew w/ the binary brush & eraser on one layer while trying to limit undos (ideally none at all) the drawings sucked compared to my normal work & were way harder at first but i learned an absolute shitton and became way more confident about working without crutches

In geometry a line is 1 dimensional, in art they're thin two dimensional shapes.
Don't treat them like a 1 dimensional boundary that you outline things with to make a drawing. Treat them like a shape that needs to be drawn, because they are the drawing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Whether it's an artist or a course, what matters is that you have a certain degree of interest in it and keep at it. From there you're bound to gain something from the time and efforts you invested into it.
Since you're already taking Proko's figure drawing course I'd recommend to watch Saitou https://www.youtube.com/@saitonaoki/videos as it will provide you with a lot of little challenges you can try to reproduce by yourself, such as this video for example https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=04wTQt5gaWY that I randomly clicked on. There are hundreds others so go and be curious.

>"pick an artist you like and copy them" makes me paralyzed...
That way you'll get to learn about what you want vs. not want to do better, because right now the biggest challenge you need to face is your mentality. Art isn't a straight road with a best objective way someone can just give you. You gotta learn what is your own way.

I've talked about this in the past, and while it's true, it's not universal. It mostly applies to the most generic, simplistic anime styles of today. The style you'd see in a generic anime video game, in generic light novel art, or in your generic isekai anime or manga. Most vtubers also use that style.
Other styles with a bit more effort, personality and skill put into them usually don't suffer from this problem, because the artist understands the concept of volume, so his style usually adapts and takes on traits that make it look a bit more unique.

>>6413837
So Copic itself is a brand. I'm not sure if it's the OG alcohol based brush marker, but it's basically the standard. I would have recommended Prismacolor last year if you didn't want to splurge on Copics, but I think they're discontinuing the line since I've been seeing them on major clearance at every art store. With that being said, you could easily get a good deal. I personally prefer Copics over all of the alternate brands (Ohuhu is my least favorite and I think they give Instagram/YouTube artists free sets for the good reviews because they kinda suck in person). If you want new, you can buy them for cheapest on Blick. After Christmas, you'll see a lot of sets for sale on sites like Mercari and that's where I got mine for a really good deal. I like that Copics are refillable, and they get a lot cheaper to use when you're refilling them. Other good Copic alternate brands I like are Kuretake and Tombow (make sure not to accidentally get their water markers). Hope this helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6423644
read 'drawing lessons from the great masters' by robert beverly hale.
practice drawing cylinders and spheres until you can draw them in such a way that they're so good they look like an optical illusion. drawing cubes is to condition your mind for perspective so you should do that as well. by practicing these shapes, your paintings will take on their nature. as an example; if you drill proficiency of spheres into your artistic ability, you will be automatically better at drawing breasts.
the book i mentioned will teach you the fundamentals so that you are well-quipped to navigate the various aspects of art. it moreso teaches you how to think like an artist, rather than simply telling you what to think.
you can already do hands better than ai so at least you've got that going for you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428274
Just got this, extremely disappointing compared to the color & light book.
I feel like color & light offered a well rounded balance of theory, technical information and examples that other books lack and is exhaustive.

The composition and narrative book is a by-the-numbers text dump of golden ratio, rule of thirds, dark foreground, light background type stuff and offers no examples from Greg Rutkowski himself via thumbnails/sketches or other studies to show practical examples.

Framed Ink 1 & 2, Creative Illustration by Loomis and Edgar Paynes composition of outdoor painting all offer much more.

3DTotal back to their usual low quality books.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6435278
You can learn anatomy in med school, but you still won't be able to draw it well. Figure drawing is learning to draw the figure. Learning anatomy is purelly informational knowledge. It does help you understand what you are trying to represent, or when drawing from imagination to know where to position things, but it isn't drawing information. Most pepole say you should start with figure drawing, when you feel confortable with it but you feel you are being held back by not knowing the specifics of the muscles and body parts, then you go to anatomy.

anon, i've gone through a thousand (literally) artbooks and his books are LITERALLY the only ones that a beginner can actually use
everything else is requires someone else who is better at drawing than you to go through the book with you to teach you what is garbage information, what to ignore, etc.

one case in particular, Marshall Vandruff mentioned that the How to Draw book by Scott Robertson is really great in the first half but absolutely garbage in the second half
stuff like this is a common occurrence with artbooks so if you're an actual lbeginner, I'd say ignore everything else and stick with this guy's books until you know a little more about drawing to be able to filter out the garbage from other books

About my only gripe is that Diane barely has any art in the book compared to the other characters, and there aren’t a lot of shorthand sketches of their final designs. Still, probably the best artbook I own.

posts.com:
Any anons with OCD on /ic/?

Watching webm related (drawn by myself) makes me extremely anxious.
Sometimes I start thinking about my own arm while drawing and it starts to hurt like a motherfucker, an imaginary pressure that wells ups and I have to stop drawing until it goes away.

Sometimes I can't sit still because my body itches all over the place and I want to take off my clothes.

Drawing has helped me a bit to overcome these issues by force, when I accept some imperfection without correcting it or when I purposely draw it wonky, like the zipper in this webm. But the fact that it's done in so few strokes is still nervewrecking, my wish is to do lift the pen at each curve to ensure it's perfect.

Tell me your drawing autisms.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6455421
1. Wear drawing gloves (or in my case, a sock). This is important so that your hand can glide; it makes a difference.
2. Flip canvas horizontal or rotate canvas for awkward drawing angles. Everybody has a natural angle they're better at drawing lines with.
3. Stabilizer. Crank that shit up so your lines are smooth even when drawing with your arm (drawing with the arm can sometimes cause wobbles). Use this to a second pass on your drawings since stabilizer can mess up the flow of sketching.
4. Too much pressure sensitivity on a brush can be a noob trap. Try using stiffer brush sensitivity until you've gotten control of that.
5. Practice re-inking manga (tracing but you're going for a high level of reproduction). Have a window open of the reference to refer to as well. Doing 3-4 of these with a high level of precision will teach you a lot.
6. Hopefully you have a medium-sized tablet; the small models are a bit cramped.
7. If you have a wacom model, go for the flex nibs. They're softer and so have a superior feel over the hard plastic nibs.
8. Have patience with yourself, there's a lot that goes into linework. I use only a screenless tablet and many people who do good linework also do. Understanding what your hands need to draw good lines is the first step.

Here's the pen if you want it, it's for clip studio: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1edmT5vRR_7IjscccuhAbDw3w5n8NtlLp/view?usp=sharing

>>6455421
My attempt, used hard round with no stabilizer on. Depending on what you're making, e.g black and white manga or lineart to colour in, you should take a different approach. I tried making lineart that could be considered relatively finished without adding colour.

Generally though, unless your lineart is what you want to focus on more than anything else, It's something that will improve pretty naturally as you get better. Most people who struggle with basic lineart don't have particularly good sketches to begin with.

For instance, a common issue with beginners that struggle with lineart is the use of really messy and loose sketches, which look ok at first, but are really hard to work with when explicit decisions have to be made on the placement of lines.

posts.com:
The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.
Post resources, questions, in-progress pages, breakdowns of other works, etc. If a work is not yours, credit the maker (unless it's fucking obvious like a full page of One Piece or something).
Thanks to everyone for making /mmg/ a level-headed and helpful place. Remember, drawing and making comics and manga are difficult endeavors, and we're all in this struggle together.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6449929
It's very good for making manga (page by page format) and webtoons (scrolling format).
Pretty much every professional that makes manga digitally uses it.
It has all the tools you need and the free assets store has a ton of stuff to make the creation process even easier like premade speech bubbles, manga backgrounds, effects brushes, 3d models and so on.
My only gripe with clipstudio is that the lettering system is so barebones that it hurts.
It gets the job done but it does feel very clunky doing your lettering in clipstudio.
I've only made comics in paint tool sai before and compared to that clipstudio is so much better.
Also there's a ton of tutorials on the creation process both official and by fans on youtube.
Just buy it on a sale.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6454002
I have only looked at the chapters so I can't comment on the writing.

I really like the composition and artstyle even though it's pretty simple and scratchy.
It seems to fit the atmosphere quite well.

You should really think about using proper speechbubbles or if you want to keep the uniqe speechbubbles you currently use then please use a better font.
Your current font makes it look like those old scanlations of manga.
Lettering is just as important as art and composition.
Blambot.com has a lot of free and good looking comic fonts for dialogue and effects. Blambot even lets you use these fonts commercially for prints and stuff if you're an indie artist.

I can also see you're structuring the panels like a manga or comic page.
You don't have to do this on webtoon because of the infinite scrolling webtoons have.
Take advantage of this feature and give your panels more breathing room and space between each other.
It feels very crammed and overwhelming as it currently is. Remember, there are no pages on webtoons. There's just one very long page pretty much.
Look at how popular webtoons are placing their panels.
You can do a lot of unique and fun paneling on webtoon that you couldn't do with a traditional page-to-page layout.

Also think about using more differently shaped panels.
It's fine as it is right now but it might become boring or samey seeing the same rectangle panels as you create more chapters.


Overall it looks good and promising. Godspeed anon!

>>6454002
I read the full thing. I though it was great, main thing I dislike is the dialogue. You should change the font, have speech bubbles, and also just go over everything to remove unnecessary lines, and edit forced lines. I'm also working on a comic, and it's definitely a challenge to make dialogue seem natural and not cringe-inducing. Try and act out the interaction in your head, and ask yourself if it would be like that in a real life interaction. Also keep in the mind that the character's personality plays a role in each interaction (If you haven't done this already, you should write down a document for yourself that includes your character's personality, motivations, fears, etc..) And another thing to keep in mind is that not everything has to be vocalized.

I found it weird how this main character knows English well when she was abandoned as a little kid, I think she should be more mute (Or maybe you could make her dialogue have a purposefully limited choice of words.) And like the other anon said, it should be explained how she built an entire house by herself, knows how to cook, and how she has money.

Overall I thought this was pretty cool and I'm looking forward to your revisions and more chapters.

>>6457257
Initially I was going to do the goku thing, where no matter what direction he faces the hair magically looks the same. But I found that's much harder to do with hair that isn't black. I also have been skimming several manga titles that have unusual hair styles and find that their authors really do avoid certain angles almost completely. I started out with more cartoonish art that simplified the problem but I've moved towards more detailed stuff but refuse to change the hairstyle I'm attached to. Another thing I noticed was how few mangakas want to draw forehead slopes at a 3/4 angle. Damn near everybody has bangs/fringe to cover that up.

posts.name: Anonymous

Nice, colors look good. One thing I'll say though is that because the shapes aren't totally accurate, some of the magic of the light source is lost. E.G.: the match flame in the ref is sitting in his cupped hand, and the light coming through the fingers emphasizes this. Your flame is about the same distance from the cigarette, but the hand is further away, so it doesn't quite sell the illusion of the skin glowing in the same way - it looks sort of like there's a second, invisible flame further towards his palm. This is hugely nitpicking though, thanks for posting.

It depends on what you want out of a drawing program. Do you see yourself animating or
working on multi-page long-form comics? Do you use a lot of stamp brushes or patterns in your work? lots of filters? If the answer is yes then CSP is probably what you want. I'll say that when it comes to the the tools that artists who like the brushes REALLY like the brushes so it's worth checking out at least once.

This isn't even an advanced program but it just works. I think the reason is that it only works in Windows so it's super fast. Every other program is made to work with linux so they always use a heavy toolkit like QT that slows down everything.
Try drawing in SAI and in CSP without stabilizer. CSP is heavy so the brush starts lagging behind. SAI is light so it instantly draws the strokes to your cursor.

What is /ALT/?
If you're looking for a place to post your cartooning then you've found the right general. This is /ic/s 1st and only merged hub where both Eastern and Western stylization can coexist peacefully, hence the double title.
>Rules & Guidelines
(1) Any form of cartooning is welcome; so submit and receive feedback from others. (2) Please resize your images before posting. (3) Share your knowledge and (4) Remember to not be afraid of asking for critique. Most importantly, keep discussion at a civil level
>I came for anime. Why does the image OP say cartoons general?
To distinguish from the anime study thread (janitor supported). Please post your studies there and personal work goes here.
------
>Community Resources
>Tag the OP if you want a resource included here.

posts.com: Does anyone else feel like being a renderfag halted their progress? I had to go through a year without painting any of my drawings, instead focusing solely on the underdrawing and inks as much as possible. I'm slowly returning to painting, just wondering if anyone has experienced a similar phenomenon.

yeah, i also was much better at rendering than at anything else.

i can't wait to go back to rendering though, i can feel that what i've learned plus my rendering could produce interesting results

For me it wasn't any particular artist but learning just how important it was to see and think with a pencil and ink. I do a lot of thumbnailing in black and white now, so I'll let the shadow shapes guide me as to what should be drawn. I was looking at a Jungle Book art book so that's where served as inspiration for this piece. I do a lot of erasing and let random paint strokes from the positive and negative shapes create new ideas, so sometimes the final image doesn't always come out as planned.

I don't use Twitter or anything like that, I don't even remember how I found Gloss but I do remember that I liked his art immediately.
His construction and foreshortening is rock solid, his anatomy is on point, his figures are dynamic and expressive, his composition is impactful, and his rendering looks really nice on top of all of that. Not to mention that he has a fairly broad range, stylistically. If you check out his visual novel project Sweet Canvas you'll notice that the way that he paints his characters' faces ranges from super abstracted (like Kanna, who's my favorite desu) to more defined and "realistic" (like Io, for instance). I really would have to disagree with his art being "uninspired", Gloss is SOVL as fvck.

posts.com:
>>6453318
Grayscale to color.
Simply because you work with value first and then you apply color to it. So far, I found the cons of this method is that you work with limited amount of color, it means its hard for you to play around with its color variation, hue, or maybe saturation unless you finished painting your entire composition, you can only work with any shade of gray that you put there in the first place. You also need to have better understanding of your own software since this method relies 90% on it. That being said, you have to learn about your brushes, opacity option (Multiply, Overlay, Color, etc), also blending and other software related things. The pros of this method is that you could easily make a color harmony, color grading, and set the entire tone/mood of your composition. You can also set ambient occulsion or any other screen effect with this method.

posts.com: Greyscale requires a little more effort to get to the same end result, but it's the most forgiving when it comes to exploration. You can try out a bunch of color palettes without affecting your values, whereas with color you have to make sure what colors you use are the ones you want or paint multiple versions. Fixing that afterwards takes a lot more time if you decide it isn't working.

posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

if you haven't tried the memorization technique, now would be a good time to try it, especially if you're going for simpler studies like for the features.

Make a study
Put away the reference / previous drawing
Draw it again

This will really help the shapes you are studying in Morpho come out in your imaginative drawing

>>6378026
I have the opposite problem, I took a painting class years ago and can only fix things or add detail by reshaping blobs of "paint". My skills have degraded from absence and I'm playing catchup, but my eyes are still ok. I'd like some help on that, but for your problem:

Usually a person has a preference for what kind of style of painting they want, even if they aren't consciously thinking about a certain era of painting. Here are some things to keep in mind while painting:
Do you like it when it looks like you painted it, or do you want to hide it?
Are little details fun or annoying? How about highlights?
There are many ways to make a focal point, which way do you like?

And when you've figured this out, you bend more towards that direction. Since this is the master study thread, you eyeball the art movements on wikipedia or something and say, "that one". For example, someone who doesn't enjoy painstaking detail and wants a painterly look, but likes little flourishes may study impressionist artists.

I know this was posted a while ago but given how complicated the original seems to be, how did you go about starting this study? I still stumble over my own feet when doing master studies of complex work

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6400090
spend quite some time doing line art
then paint all the big shape first squint my eyes till it has similar value and color contrast (since I don't try to make it the exact color from the rei one)
when both are done the rest is just mindless zooming in and filling/rendering all the small stuff following the line while zooming out to double-check the big picture with rei one
then paint over the line and redraw some of it
notice that rei is using a different technique here with clean line art and sticking to it so the edge is cleaner and can change line art color a lot. which is hard for me to do since the ref is kinda blurry and I'm lazy so I draw loosely then paint over and redraw some of the line art

i got a question

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6427376
It feels really pedantic at first but you need be able to copy things exactly. When other artists do something successfully, the copying skill will let you figure out how to do it for yourself, so it unlocks a lot of learning to be able to do it right. You are already starting to get the even more important thing though, which is that exact copying forces you to develop your ability to see.

>>6431161
Oh it just looks sort of blocky like the Bridgman figures. You have the right idea in schematizing the block in but it needs to be a little more accurate. The values also look like they're done visually despite the planarization, so the dimensionality gets reduced. Speaking of values, this is a total pain but you should try to clean them up more. Literally sharpen your pencil to the finest point you can and fill in the little white dots on the paper, then go in with a kneaded eraser and pick out all the spots that are too dark. It'll be a huge pain in the ass but it will make your shadows especially look way flatter and give much more the illusion of depth, reality, and completeness.

>How is pc98 art made?
Artists would first draw the image on a physical piece of paper.
The paper would be scanned through a contemporary scanner.
After that, imperfections would be fixed and artists could begin with color and shading.
>is it possible to replicate with modern hardware?
Yes.
There are plenty of "pixelator" filters in modern software that can give you a good template.
Use a 16-color palette to block in your colors, then for rendering apply your dithering knowledge using specialized pixel art brushes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6439215
Several years ago I was very interested in this type of art. PC-98 games typically run at 640x400 resolution with 16 colors (although in practice there are often only 15 colors because one is indexed as transparent). There are actually rules as to which color values can be used, but there's no need to be so hardcore because the color choices are *practically* unlimited and nobody would be able to tell whether or not your colors would truly be possible on a PC-98 without analyzing the RGB values for each one.
There isn't one way these images were made. some artists sketched line art on paper, scanned, touched up and colored in a paint app. Some drew their lines directly in the paint app. What's needed from the paint app is:
1. Indexed painting mode, which assigns each pixel in your image to an index of your palette. If you change the color at that index, all the pixels in the image assigned to that index also change color.
2. Dithering tools. At a bare minimum, you need the ability to paint and fill using different patterns. Usually the standard dithering patterns are included but you can also create your own (helpful for doing textures, etc.). Some apps let you create custom gradients from your palette and automatically have dithering applied between each color.
Probably the two best Windows apps for doing this type of art are ProMotion and GrafX2. ProMotion is sort of the pixel art equivalent of Photoshop, as in being feature-rich and "industry standard" among serious pixel artists. It has everything you need, but can be overwhelming to use because of all the stuff you might not need. GrafX2 is simple and lightweight (and FREE) but its interface is a holdover from the 1990s and lacks some of the quality-of-life features people nowadays are used to having in their software. Both of these programs are based on Deluxe Paint 2, a very different paradigm from Photoshop that will take some getting used to if that's your frame of reference.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I remember I saw some pc98 threads on /v/ and was inspired so I spent a few hours finding all the files and got multipaint working but my my tablet wasn't working properly so I drew something with a mouse. If you wanted to draw pc98 art I would just recommend using whatever drawing program you like, look up the limitations and stick by them in your program of choice. The era appropriate multipaint has no layers, I think saving images is a bit cooked due to the emulator, tablets don't work properly, the UI is way worse than what you have now. The only thing it had going for it was the dithering brush and I'm assuming most modern programs will have something similar.
Basically if you want to do some "experimental history" you can try and get it all working but it also comes with the authentic frustration of using old computers, if you want to draw in that style just use a modern program, limit the resolution to 640x400 and use full black, full white, and only 16 other colours.
https://twitter.com/PC98_bot I'm sure there are also other places to find images made on the pc98

That's not correct. Color depth was 18 bits per pixel, or 6 bits each per R, G, and B values. 2^6 = 64 so it would be the equivalent of only having multiples of 4 from 0 to 252.

that doesn't make sense. the specs i see show 4096 colors to choose from which is 12-bit color. that's RGB444 where 16^3 = 4096. 18-bit color would need at least 3 bytes compared to using only 2 for 12-bit color. if you use pc98 painting software like multipaint, the choices you get for colors are 0-15, ie 4 bit

>>6445156
>Semi exposed breasts where you'd clearly see the areola, but for some reason it's not there
Areolas vary in size, some of them can have a large radius.
>Artist work is amazing, he vanishes from the face of the earth
I in no way want to imply I'm amazing, but I formed a decent following in the short time I posted with a pseudonym.
In my experience, as a young man, I started to cringe to the things I drew and got me a piece of the internet's attention. I found out that this wasn't a part of me that I wanted to keep developing, I couldn't be proud of the things I did. I mean, would you show the anime girl with 10k likes on twitter to your mother? With a straight face? Would you present yourself with a lady saying you are an "anime artist"? I concluded that it was a distraction that would lead me nowhere except meeting geeks and weirdos.
I think the same thing applies to some of the so called nsfw artists that are somewhat competent at their craft, even more if they are young (18-24) and still are figuring out who they want to be and what path they want to choose, what ideal of a man they strive to become.
The only positives I got from doing this online art thing was the fact that I could buy any collectible figure I wanted at any time, I just needed to open a commission slot for whatever the figure price was and that was it, not much to be proud of. The acquaintances I met? Long far gone since I yanked everything. The experiences I had online? Time wasted in my opinion.

Can't see anyone on his mid 40's drawing anime girls for a living and not being miserable, conscious of it or not. Maybe most of those artists in your mind came to the same conclusion and that's why they vanished.

posts.com:
This is my OC Mimi and her cat Nico.

Nico is a species of cat that can't digest food on its own and instead ejects its intestines out of its mouth and down Mimi's throat to absorb the halfway digested nutrients from Mimi's stomach.
It's intestines release a chemical that makes Mimi feel happy and satiated making this a symbiotic relationship between the two. Because Mimi doesn't have many friends Nico's companionship and the chemicals it provides her is enough to let her live a happy life.

Mimi is just in a hospital gown for now but she wears anything she finds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6447084
Very cute! Thank you so much anon.
I really love the intelligence and creativity behind the box, at first it was lost on me, but then I realized this is actually a reference to schrodinger's cat, the often cited example for quantum mechanics wherein a cat inside a box can be either alive or dead and exists in a superposition between the two until someone is able to observe it which snaps it into one of the two states.
Naturally this is usually applied to cats and not girls, so the subversion by having Mimi in the box as opposed to Nico parallels their relationship as well, as cats are normally the pets of humans in charge, because of Mimi's reliance on Nico, Nico is the one that is often perceived to be in charge, which in turn is represented by Mimi being the cat inside the box, a beautiful subversion of the commonly known theory.

I also recognize as a cardboard box this is likely riffing off of Hideo Kojima-san, inventor of the stealth genre as he popularized and invented the use of cardboard boxes in his hit series metal gear solid. The cardboard box naturally evokes feelings of stealth due to this genre defining game, and in the words of Hideo Kojima himself
>When I first invented the stealth genre, I landed on cardboard boxes to act as stealth. Because of their innocent nature and ability to hide counterfeit goods under the guise of normal items people will see them as basic foundations of the world and overlook them. This is really where the strand-gameplay was first born
The cardboard box being a innocent item in society is a metaphor to the seemingly innocent nature of both Mimi and Nico, where people see them and only perceive them as an innocent young girl and her cute cat, but secretly they harbor a darkness within them that's hidden away from the world around them.

Overall I think this is a brilliant drawing that perfectly captures the deeper themes of my OCs in such a perfectly succinct manner.

Do you have an OC you'd like drawn?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428037
Jdownloader2 is a download manager. It automatically saves links from direct download hosts when you copy them and organizes them in a queue. You can then choose when you want the downloads to start. It has many other functions, such as downloading all images from 4chan threads, or from Sadpanda, or saving Youtube videos with subtitles. It can also encode links in a "DLC" file, which offers a layer of protection for those files.
Even though JDownloader2 is free and open source software, the installer is often packaged with adware from places like CNet. The JAR version is just a self-extracting java-based zip file, which in theory is adware free.
I make no guarantees. Scan every software you download and make sure you read installation screens carefully, all the usual things you should be doing already.

I'd disagree. I think it can matter a lot.

They would need to somehow find a lot of the different socials I'm posting with (which have different usernames), with a lot of my work being posted to obscure enough places like 4chan (which is notoriously bad at making things easy to find through archives). I don't plan on posting a lot to mainstream social media, so it shouldn't be easy to google for.

Additionally it looks like; the more isolated and simple a concept, the easier it is to train against. For example an individual character surrounded by a blank background. So if I have a particular IP or story I want to be protective of, I'd focus on posting work that's difficult to train against like that. So mostly complex finished pieces, that have a lot of different things going on, lots of perspective etc. I genuinely think this would be a meaningful deterrent. They could maybe copy some of the style with these pieces, but not so easily the content.

Like the reason why the Sam Does Arts models are so effective, are because he'd draw the same thing over and over again in a similar way, with relatively simple backgrounds etc. Then he'd have a massive body of work easily accessible through one or two mainstream sites.

>>6455834
This style is both simple and difficult. Simple because it is black and white and a little flat color one can reproduce this even in real life with one single black ink pen. But difficult because you only got black line so you need to rely on solids and hatching to create midtones which both takes work and you need to be able to judge the form well to know where to put those midtones without making it look off. You also need to play a lot with rim lights to make the form edges come out well.

Do you have some more specific questions? This looks pretty much the standard comic style.

1. Copy a bunch of the drawings from it to get used to the shapes and line quality.
2. Modify and redraw parts of it yourself (give a character a new hairstyle, different facial expressions, a new pose) while trying to keep the style.
3. Put it all together - draw your own characters in that style and, literally, copy and paste them into the comic to see if it looks accurate on those backgrounds or next to other characters.

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

>>6455260
Most of the boxes are fundamentally failing to follow one of the most important tenants of lesson 1:

Be intentional and make quick, confident lines. Ghost, start at a point, shoot out, and /dedicate to the line you have created/. It can be tempting to make your stuff again, etc, but focus on quality. Once you finish your box, try going over the outermost edges to add lineweight to the silhouette. Finally, add /intentionally/ shaded sides. Stop scratching over the same line ten times!

Be deliberate, be confident.

>>6455300
I'll respond positively, or at least attempt to -- because I'll assume you responded out of frustration and I want to be empathetic of that.

You are competent enough to check your perspective with a ruler. And seem to own one, based off the fact that you've drawn lines to check your perspective. That skill can be honed through your own careful observation. Take time when you make a box to ask yourself what exactly is throwing it off, then check with the ruler to see if your guess was correct. This will help guide your intuition there.

What might /not/ be immediately obvious and something you can check is the mindset you put yourself in when you are putting pen to paper, and I can empathize with the scratchy drawings because I've consistently done that before.

You're doing this challenge not so that you can draw a bunch of boxes. You're doing it so you can improve your art, and improvement of your art will come from perspective growth (something you will ALREADY get out of the exercise) and general improvements of your headspace -- the decision to put intention to each mark.

Empathy over. improve your work in /all/ facets of its craft, or stay ignorant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6455594
I ain't an expert or anything but im pretty sure the key at that age for getting good at something is just seeing to it that they continue to have fun with it and have positive reinforcement, like external reinforcement from you non-patronizingly complimenting her shit giraffes. That is at least until she's able to get that positive gratification from her own inner matrix. Really, enjoyment's the key for learning at any age but the great thing for kids that age is that they're too stupid to acknowledge the demoralizing reality outside of their own fun. So don't force her to sit through a 6 hour art theory lecture just yet and she'll probably continue to be motivated just by the joy of it. As well as as long as you continue to let her enjoy art in general(80% of the reason most of us are here is we liked and consumed a lot of comics, manga, anime, animated movies, etc)

If she sticks with it long enough then try to challenge her so she doesn't coast on "talent" but leaving that up to her own initiative is probably better for getting her to actual stick through and learn. So ya, get her some "how to draw anime" or similar low level children art books that she can choose to engage with or just enjoy the art of and maybe even one or so the basics 'big boy' art books so she can catch a glimpse at how high the ceiling really goes. Even if she does go "boring" and doesn't read it for 5 years.

Maybe others can give better suggestions but for a more "advanced" book, "Pen & Ink Drawing" by Alphonso Dunn, was one of the first i owned and i think it's visually pretty interesting and varied in subject so not completely boring to look through, as like say "Keys to Drawing" was for me, and the actual text itself touches broadly on a number of good beginner subjects. It's all line art though so idk if that's a good fit if she prefers like markers, colored pencils, etc. Bottom line, just don't force it, she's 6, kids like to draw and it probably won't last.

>>6455594
>What can I do to foster/help her learn properly?
when i look back to when i was younger, i sometimes got expensive stuff which i ended up not using because it was too expensive to replace. now that i buy stuff myself for things i do, i never buy the best thing, i buy the stuff i can easily replenish/replace. i don't buy a nice 15$ sketchbook. i buy minimalist sketchbooks for $2-3, copy paper and have 20 of the same pencils at my desk. not saying you should buy her that, but my argument is that a scarcity mindset will put her off to actually draw.

so, i bought a wooden mannequin and stepped away from drawing portraits to focus more on my forms and gestures and drawing bigger parts of the body. i've been wondering why my drawings came out better with a mechanical pencil and i think it's because it glides better and so my lines get looser. currently trying to transfer this feeling to normal pencils. also have been more focused on showing planes and less silhouettes.

>>6455375
my issue with guides that tell newbies to "Just draw!" is that most people new to drawing that are reading the guides are probably older and have the intention to improve their drawing skills. they're more conscious of mistakes which is really hard to get used to. i personally almost got filtered by being unable to make a straight line after hours of practice, like it seems so simple and i've made lines with a pencil all my life, why is it so difficult? i think starting with drawing simple, natural things like rocks, sticks, and dead trees are the best start since those naturally have imperfections so your own imperfect lines and shading will still result in something that looks like a rock or a stick. i think a lot of people naturally start with trying to draw things like human faces which are pretty complicated and any issues will be immediately apparent

this has nothing to do with "intermediate artists" it has to do with intermediate skill in copying and DAB has nothing to do with copying or observational ability--at least the useful parts of it

also, i have found it is better for a beginner to learn how to copy before they learn perspective or how to draw a box in order to avoid frustration in the future, the way copying is downplayed for a typical artist is to his detriment as most artists copy in some way or another

here is the lesson plan i would typically recommend if you're an acttual absolute beginner
>line control and shapes (first lesson of DAB)
>observational ability (that infographic above)
>perspective (marshall vandruff and D'amelio)
>form (haven't found a good one yet)
>else

It took me about a year to learn how to dip pen, and even after a year I can only complete an ink drawing, but its like 10% of my competency with a micron. I’d say they are pretty hard to learn. Micron being the easiest. Ink and brush being the hardest. The consistency of the ink and the type of paper make a huge difference in what is achievable with dip pen.

Some general tips
- clean your nib between each dip
- try lots of different papers, cheap paper can tear and bleed so doing detailed work is hard. Water color paper can be too textured so doing detailed work is hard
- change your nib often especially if you arent using the zebra gold nibs or if you are about to use an old nib that you havent used in over a month.
- add water to your ink if its too thick, let your ink air out for a few days if it is too thin. Thick ink pools on the nib and it ‘whiffs’ and no lines are made. Thin ink bleeds on the paper.
- dirty nibs wont draw and the ink pools on the nib and wont run. Clean with soapy water and / or use a lighter to burn off the oils. Don’t touch the nib with your fingers, use pliers.
- if you are right handed work from left to right and top to bottom to avoid smearing
- use a shot glass or something for the ink to avoid contamination
- get a feel for the direction you can draw in. nibs dont like moving side to side or making up strokes like you can with a micron or brush. They only pull down, so commit to rotating the paper instead of shortcutting and pushing the nib.
- move fast, don’t linger or you will get line tremors and pooled ink

Dip pen takes quite a bit of finesse to get it right. It’s basically adding a 3rd dimension to your inking since you now have x, y and z (pressure) for line weight.

>>6451998
This is completely wrong. Blind leading the blind!
Perspective (linear perspective, to be precise) is a set of rules that govern the drawing of a subject *from a single point of view.* One of the characteristics of perspective is that parallel lines which recede from the viewer appear to converge toward a vanishing point; put another way, any object, or the distance between any two points, will appear smaller the farther away it is from the viewer.
People often misuse the word perspective, as in "isometric perspective." This is like saying "square circle." Isometric projection is a type of orthographic drawing. In orthographic drawing, there is no size diminution as objects recede in space. But there may still be foreshortening, because foreshortening and perspective are not the same! Foreshortening is simply the effect of viewing a particular plane or surface in such an aspect that it does not appear at its full length or width, i.e. it is turned away from the picture plane. When you see a human face from the front, the sides of the head are foreshortened.
In picrel (hexagonal prism in isometric projection, grabbed from YouTube), distances UP and SR are equal, which would not be the case in a perspective drawing because SR is further back in space. But the face TU is clearly foreshortened.
If you were to draw a subject as seen from a theoretically infinite distance, there would be no trace of perspective, but there would still be foreshortening. The size distortion of perspective is greater the closer you get to the subject. Look at a very distant cityscape, versus a view of the buildings from within the city. The former almost has the appearance of an orthographic projection.

posts.com:
it's the wild west right now so just do what you want. if you care about ethics but still want to use AI i guess you can avoid using artist names in prompts and models that aim to replicate specific artists, but keep in mind that all models are made using images scraped on the internet, they need it to work.
using img2img on its own is helpful for suggestions and brainstorming but not for finished pieces imo, as even with low denoising strength it changes too much.
i've also used ai generated works as reference for my own, mostly because there were aspects of composition and color in the generated image that i liked.
i do see potential in training an ai model on your own style and then using that model to generate new images in your style, either with txt2img or img2img, but i haven't tried it yet.

>>6396806
Soft shading/lighting with fewer steps. Gotta tweak the airbrush settings because default airbrush settings are often bad. If you use CSP, consider getting the “airy airbrush” tool. You can get similar results blocking in color on a higher layer then using a soft eraser, but a good airbrush will do that all on its own. Imo, it’s an essential tool for ani semi-realistic soft shading.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A good artstyle is generally not an "aesthetic island." It most likely can be added to, modified, and done differently with as you wish; and you can often find artists who are in a similar vein with other artists (esp. with anime). Even if not followed to the tee, you will end up with something that's still good by copying your favorite artists.

If you copy very different artists you will need to go the route of harmonizing the different shape language you pick up from them and finding where you personally want to go with. This is just a matter of experimentation and working through things. It's a process I am used to at least.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6456500
Honestly, it's the best tip that you could give, even more in sites like this one.
Most people want the MaGiC tRiCk that'll make them draw good art but there's no shortcut to good art. You gotta draw. That's it.
Everybody keeps complaining about their skills but they draw once every three months.
Just fucking start drawing, take the awful drawing out of you, hate your art. Try copying artist you like and you'll have a clearer idea of what you lack.
Yes, you'll think that everything looks awful but you'll start noticing that you can't draw simple shapes, or your perspective is always wrong, or your poses look stiff and THAT'S when you'll stop copying artist to try to improve a specific thing that YOU think will help you, so you'll be motivated to learn.

TLDR: It is the best tip for the lazy "artist" that just complain instead of draw.

If your goal is solely the end result, that is, if you just need a way to generate an image from what you have in your head, there's no reason to dedicate years of your life on drawing.

Why you should not trust youtube shills:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Twy5Wo8m284

If you have any additional questions, ask them.
Remember to ignore all chinese shills.

>I'm thinking of getting the Wacom One, should I buy it?
Fuck off retard. Ask a better question.

Recommended tablets:

>Intuos 3
Best screenless tablet. Look for one on Craigslist or Ebay.
>Intuos 4, 5 & Pro
Also good options. Will burn through your nibs.
>Samsung Galaxy Tab S6 Lite
Budget portable display tablet. Very solid drawing experience with Wacom EMR tech, but a small 10.4" display area.
>Used iPad Pro 2nd Gen 12.9"
Best option for a display tablet.
>Galaxy Tab S7+/S8+
Good premium alternative to an iPad Pro
>One by Wacom (not Wacom One)
Solid cheap option

Avoid:

>XP-Pen, Huion, Gaomon and every other Chinese brand
Poor build quality, lackluster pens, broken tilt, struggles to register light pressure, horrible customer support and the displays are not calibrated. All Chinese brands have the same problems. Check out the webm to understand how bad they are. Also watch out, Chinese companies shill HARD on /ic/; they do a lot of samefagging and frequently hurl personal insults.

>Microsoft Surface Pro
The N-Trig digitizer means you will always get wobbly lines.

>Lenovo
Bad drawing performance because they're not designed with art in mind.

>iPads (brand new) - Bad value
>iMacs and Macbooks - Never buy this garbage under any circumstance. It's a locked ecosystem with rubbish hardware you can't upgrade.

Previous: >>6383408

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6453196
Well anon for a real answer it has a lot of qualities that are attractive and at least worth talking about.

Balance, contrast, rhythm, focal points. These things exist in most representational art, but here they exist kind of by themselves, deconstructed.

Lines, curves, shapes in representational drawing are tools, means to an end. Here they are the subject, the focus.

You can see how in some spots, even two lines create the suggestion of 3d space, not any real space mind you, but a sort of abstraction of 3d space itself.

You can see how colored shapes interact almost like they are transparent stained glass. Not necessarily following the actual color theory rules of how they'd interact, but still reading as color interactions of that sort.

It's like molecular/deconstructed cuisine. A way of treating the ingredients in a different way, of letting them take a life of their own.

posts.com: What exactly is the difference between an irl photo looking off and a drawing looking off?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6453184
An unmanipulated photo likely looks off from lens warp/distortion which is a consistent kind of distortion. A drawing is an inconsistent distortion that is essentially randomized depending on what the artist can or can't measure accurately. In a weird photo, say the entire outer edge is stretched unnaturally. In a drawing, you might have everything look accurate to life except the hand or nose or whatever. Camera lens distortion is one reason your front camera on a phone makes your nose look bigger than it is. The nose is closer to the lens than the rest of the face. But if someone drew you, your nose would look fine but they could randomly fuck up your left eye or something.
