posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6449852
1/2
Was thinking about this just this morning. AI is definitely a wakeup call but certainly not the death of the artist. It has its place and use as a tool of convenience.

I think we'll have to adapt in much the same way that AI does. Specifically, by rejecting digital mediums for the physical, relearning traditional techniques, and developing a unique style after figuring out some fundies. Many art communities online are having absolute meltdowns because they can't tell the difference between an AI piece and an original work even though the funny shit is the vast majority of people online are using digital and tablets. There's a very simple workaround for this: make your art physically. Sure some pajeet can make a robot that can emulate skill, but no pajeet will replace the human soul. Trads don't have to give a shit, just post timestamp.

Personally, digital artwork lacks a lot of appeal in the first place. Not to say it isn't or can't be good, I just think it's missing something fundamental to the human soul that goes into it. The mistakes are too easily corrected, the physicality of touching paper, oils, color, spilling shit and just getting weird with it are gone. Spill coffee on your computer and you could lose a keyboard, spill coffee on a canvas and it can be inspiring. AI gives me the feeling people are seeing with their eyes whether or not a piece has appeal, and not their heart. Some of the dumbest shit speaks to me even if it's not some high ideal, but so far, AI hasn't. It simply doesn't have a human soul to connect with.

I'm predicting a renaissance of physical, traditional, and certainly original art soon as a natural counter to AI and looking forward to it. We'll end up with a lot of weird growing pains but I truly think it'll pay off. Once you can show something was made with your own hands, there can be no further doubt to authenticity. Mark my words, in the coming years a selling point to media will be a "all human art team."

No it won't work.
I have had at least 3 sreen less tablets (2 Wacoms, 1 Huion), 2 Screen tablets (Huion 13 pro, Huion 22 plus) and an Ipad pro 1st gen. For any of the classic tablets even if they say the have 60º of tilt sensitivity, when they get to about 30º from the tablet the side of the pen hits the tablet and the tip stops touching the tablet and it sopts regitering.

The closest you would get to ergonomics with the common overhand grip would be the iPad pro, but even or that the brishes are all over the place. Even for something that looks like it has been done with the overhand grip - like lanedraws - its probably just a 60º or less tilt on the apple pencil and making the brush size way bigger. There are a fair good number of videos from lanedraws drawing on you tube. check those out, they will surely be helpful.

AIs will kill the market way earlier than a good pen disblay is develped that allows for a good experience with an overvand grip - unfortunately.

>he underside of the chin is right there?
It's not. While I'm not autistic, I do have an autistic obsession with detail, and one of the things I always struggled with when learning to draw animu shit was figuring out how the chin was supposed to look when drawn from a lower angle, and how it connects to the neck/throat, because so many animu artists ignore it or just flat out don't know how to draw it. In the same vein, a lot of animu artists rely on side-mouth, despite the fact that it looks horrid, and serves as no shortcut if you know how to draw a proper mouth from the side. It's just a flaw that somehow turned into an excuse for style.
If you look at 3D models of anime characters, some Japs have made a career out of cheating a 2D look out of a 3D model, by making everything move independent of reality, which speaks volumes about how some anime styles just make no sense.
As an aside, don't take my criticism as a personal attack. It's nice to have a civil discussion in this shithole for once.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6442749
virtually nobody draws the actual eyeball and you probably don’t either
eyeballs are really, really fucking small relative to visible eye structures, which in combination with the convex iris taking up so much of the frontal plane leads to the extreme dynamism of the eye
in contrast, anime eyeballs, if approached as such, would be absolutely massive relative to the visible eye, to the point that they would be clipping each other and the skull in order to achieve the relative flatness of the visible structure
what 90% of people, and all the examples posted itt, do is draw a circle roughly lining up to one eyelid in whatever perspective and considering that an eyeball, when in reality they’re drawing a simplified ocular cavity and drawing the eyelid along one edge and ad libbing the other, which is why the perspective makes no sense and why it looks so flat and symbol drawn despite supposedly being constructed, it’s just marking off where to curve the eyelid on the frontal plane of the face with extra steps

which is fine, because the typical anime eye is not spherical and doesn’t condone an actual eyeball, it’s a flattened stylisation of the surface structure of the eye
yes, there’s a degree of 3d structure to it, and yes there’s a degree of anatomical foundation to it, but it’s a flattened surface structure
people are told to learn about real eyes so they can manipulate that understanding of the surface structure of the eye into an anime stylisation of it, but retards hear this and think it means they’re to be approached the same way

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6450840
>drawabox
No wonder drawing makes you feel like ass. I can't imagine doing that crap and I've been drawing for years. I don't know if it'll help but I'll lend you some of my advice. Pick your favorite artist you want to draw like and start copying their stuff. Not serious 1:1 studies, just make some shitty doodles with whatever looks cool to you. In my case I just copied Akira panels because I always loved it. I must've copied half the series at some point. After a while I began to understand how Otomo drew figures. I didn't realize then that I was basically just doing figure studies, just not with irl people. Some time later I got confident enough to learn from other artists I admired and got better at copying, then I actually went over the fundies books that everyone pushes on prebegs. I felt like I learned in reverse but there is no wrong way to learning as long as you're making progress. Another piece of advice is to grow some skin and learn to take and LISTEN to advice from your superiors and apply it. Don't assume you know better when someone tells you this shading is inconsistent or this fold doesn't make sense etc.

Point is, while art is practice and hard work, it doesn't mean you can't have fun. Like with working out, you can make fun out of activities.

>>6450706
I admit I was mad at first about AI because I felt like it was taking away my opportunity to make it as an artist, but the more I think about it:
>I never wanted to do commission work anyway, since drawing other people’s OCs seemed really boring to me, I’d rather draw my own characters
>I never wanted to draw “flavor of the month” characters, ie whatever Nintendo girl is popular right now, I just want to draw characters I like
>I never wanted to pay attention to numbers on social and obsessing over what stuff gets the most engagement, stressing over likes/retweets takes the joy out of drawing
Etc. Of course, I’d still do a lot of that stuff, just because I wanted to “make it” and not because I actually wanted to draw it. And even with doing that, the truth is the chances of “making it” were always infinitesimally low, so I’ve realized AI never took away my chance, I never had a chance in the first place.
Of course, that doesn’t mean I’m going to quit drawing, since I still enjoy drawing. It just means I can focus now on doing what I want to do, and drawing what I want to draw, and if I can get some income off of that then that’s nice, but I’m not going to go into it with the illusion that I can actually make a career off of it.
In a way, I feel like this is a healthier mentality to approach art anyway.

>>6428967
Tried out SG Pen and the Ink Brush, wasn't close to it. So I made this custom brush from a hodge podge of a bunch of brush materials I cannibalized.

I'm not particularly skilled at art, and especially at anime so sorry for the bad drawing. This was to see if I could get close to the original. It was drawn in 1600x2000 then cropped down mainly with the brush size between 12, 16, 20, 24, and 32 depending on what the line thickness is. It's not a good brush for a single line drawing. Instead, you'll have to draw over your lines multiple times to get it to be thick. Keep it light and fast for the "skippy" thin lines. I highly suggest holding your pen either the way Nagabe holds his pen for solid lines and a looser grip for the skippy ones.

https://files.catbox.moe/1ndnwq.sut

>>6455616
Well that's just filming a sexy woman dancing, then drawing over the frames you want.

Ralph Bakshi's famous for doing it cheaply. Don Bluth does it better in that you can't see the cracks as much (and that he never focussed on people)

Disney's whole animation arm was driven by this in the golden era, but they were better at hiding it. They more leant towards the reference model, rather than outright tracing like Bakshi.

>>6439630
happy new year. I am back with an interesting find.

In a past post, I mentioned that mangakas tend to copy each other in things they consider work and can apply to their own work. That's how it's always been.

I forgot to mention that the format of work for artists often incorporates assistants who, with time, adopt the style and take on features whether they want it or not, from the mangaka they work for until they manage to go independent.


Now check this:

https://nhentai.net/g/546/
https://exhentai.org/g/2045223/2ae1ebbce9/
https://exhentai.org/g/2341/c7f27363b8/
All links belong to [Kago Shintarou] Choutennou Parataxis | Super-Conductive Brains Parataxis [English]

It's an 2001 tankoubon with excellent panel clarity and readability (despite the low resolution scans).
But what interests me is the striking resemblance to Masamune Shirow's style from the late 1980s and early 1990s.
It's almost a "love letter to the author" during the first 2 chapters, with uncanny similitude in design language (character designs, expressions and objects) and mixing it with his own style evident in the rest of the tank.
I leave you with the GITS 1.5 because the one i found for the original is a mirrored edition. couldn't find the correct orientation and B&W, but it is still useful for reference.
https://mangasee123.com/manga/Ghost-In-The-Shell-15

According to my knowledge and limited research, they both have never worked together, but you'd never know given how reserved Masamune is.

By the way, speaking of Shirow Masamune. Check out pic related and then link bellow if you think stylized bodies are a detached image from reality.
https://www.pornhub.com/view_video.php?viewkey=ph55876fe18e4fb
oiled, and all

because its also works as regular battleship if none of the anti gravitational fuel is available, the flight mode cannot be sustained forever too, because of the liquids properties (has to be kept at a certain temperature and mixture with gases to work/ overheating issues etc.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6444277
>Am I actively harming my learning by using her as my reference?
Sadly, you are, since this and most 3D models have various limitations.

Muscles expand and contract in different ways from pose-to-pose that the doll isn't able to replicate here. Even AAA games have only just started to simulate stuff like this.
Since the model lacks detail you're also not seeing how the different muscles or bones might become more visible in certain poses.
(Even if you wouldn't always draw these details in a heavily stylized work it's still important to be aware of them.)
The lighting in this scene is also very soft, which works for making the model look good, but makes for a poor shading reference as the plane changes in the body aren't as clear.
Also due to rigging limitations the doll won't always contort correctly into certain poses.
By solely referencing this model you're also copying all anatomical mistakes done by the original artist.

As you don't have an accurate reference of the human body, your learning is also inaccurate.
I'd recommend grabbing a cheap professional reference pack from ArtStation, for example. I'm sure you should be able to find a model you like.

>>6450506
>>6450693
i'm by no means an expert but i think you could try focusing on two things first:
- drawing the major curves of the pose (e.g. gesture), most often this will be things like the spine curve, the angle of the hips and shoulders, the flow of the limbs
- drawing simple 3d forms like boxes and cylinders, being aware of which side is facing you and which side is facing away from you, then break the figure down into simple boxes and cylinders and try to give yourself a sense of which blocks are coming towards you or heading away, etc

Hi anon, used one of the figures you posted as part of my figure drawing today. Then I broke it into more explicit box forms. When drawing the figure on the left, I’m thinking about the forms and also about the shapes on the figure in a hybrid sort of way.

I’ll also throw my hat into the giving you advice ring, feel free to take or leave it:
I question labelling >>6450413 this one here as ‘symbol drawing’. from what I can see you’ve attempted to reproduce the shapes as you see them on the figure, which is great! I think the other anon just correctly saw that your 3-dimensional understanding of the forms in the figure was lacking. So definitely take the advice given to you about breaking the figure into forms, practice your boxes etc. But, as far as I can see, doing studies faithfully reproducing the shapes you see on the figure will do you no harm.
Rather, symbol drawing is the subconscious refusal to draw the figure as you actually see it. And that’s something that’ll haunt you well outside of being a beg. Constantly catching myself symbol drawing, as well as in this study I did here.

well I kind of am, but I want to push my rendering and people seem to like it.
I've upped them before and comms slowed down so I went back to my usual fee, which is now at 75€ per pinup. Thing is, in order for my rendering to be decent is requires more hours.I feel like a fair price would be around 120€, which,even if it takes me 7 hours, it's still a decent hourly wage.
I'm thinking on setting the baseline pinup: flat colors and highlights at 70€ [picrel] and charge extra for rendering.

Behold! My anger and frustration given form!
Other than that, I usually end up drawing girl characters that I feel I can be friends with, similar to >>6441172.
Growing up, I had some actual female friends even though I was male, and that was one of the parts of my youth that I really enjoyed. I still miss them, even though it's been decades since then. Seeing all the gendered warfare on the net just makes me miss them more.
My female characters often end up having a homely edge to them, even when I'm making them cute. I find those non-idealized elements to be cute exactly because they remind me of friendships.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Imagine being covered in sharp spines.

You snag on things,you have to watch what you do extra carefully. You can't touch anyone else, or you can hurt them. But you have so much love in your heart that you could hug the whole world. But you dare not. The loneliness he feels is profound, but he will do good anyway, bringing folk together, helping them find the love that he can only dream about.

But although he feels accursed, he's wrong. He can hug,but all he need do is take it slowly and he too can feel the affection that we all long for. His prickles are my gift to him: automatic retribution for anyone who dares try to hurt him,something I have often wished for myself, having received more than my share of inflicted pain.

>>6440506
Sadly, most everything I make is a cope with something that is missing in my life. I’m halfway convinced that if I had a healthy social life, I probably wouldn’t pick up a pen anymore, and I’d be okay with it.

I don’t self-insert or power fantasy, but instead write conversations between characters to fill the void left by my lack of a social life. I have no friends or life of my own so I create characters with lives to make me feel less lonely and give me a way to escape. I’ve often likened it to playing with action figures. It feels a lot like that used to feel.

Being a supposed adult, the whole thing is depressing and sad but the only alternative is pretending you’re not lonely while abstaining from doing pathetic things like writing your own fictional social life in comic form just so that you can cope day by day. Jfc idk I’ve said enough

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6443008
>I’m halfway convinced that if I had a healthy social life, I probably wouldn’t pick up a pen anymore, and I’d be okay with it.

After 15 years of drawing and writing stories, I have come to the same conclusion myself. I think writing stories have made me find what I really wanted in my life despite my social conditioning and what I was told I "should" want, like my stories were a reflection of my innermost desires that I was never given the permission or encouragement to realize. Now I am working towards a new lifestyle and career that would get me closer what I want and similar to what I used to write stories about, and I realized something: if I pick this lifestyle and it ended up with me never writing or drawing again... somehow I would be totally fine with that. The whole thing is kinda embarrassing but it's real and human.

>I’ve often likened it to playing with action figures. It feels a lot like that used to feel.

Yeah I compare it to that too. It feels like playing with dolls or action figures, and somehow I just never grew out of that.

>>6440506
Yes but not in the same way as most people. I find I draw to cope with the fact I find life never measures up to my expectations of what is "interesting." I have traveled, seen cultures, made friends but easily I lose interest in all these things afterwards. It's fun to learn about someone for the first few days, but afterwards I get bored once I already learn what makes people tick and I use this in my own stories. I know it's sociopathic and narcissistic so I've stopped making friends knowing I discard pretty much everyone I meet and it probably hurts them so I don't want to do that anymore to people. Fiction makes life and people more interesting than it really is. The only people I would find interesting are the 1% of people, but even then I can't be friends with interesting people as I only see socializing as a way to gain something out of it for my stories. When I start to really get to know someone I start to think I'm wasting my time and my life is unfulfilled, it only feels fulfilled when I write my stories. Fiction lets me cope with my boredom as I can create the most fantastical worlds and build off of pre-existing cultures, concepts, history, philosophy, legends, and make them more intriguing in my eyes. It's like an endless playground for me. I think it's because the real world is not romantic enough for me, I like stories of epic battles, glory, strange things, and the exotic. The real world is very interesting in that it is spiritual and mystical with strange tales to tell, but real people are not interesting. I build off what I find interesting in the real world, and make it even more fascinating or perfect in my eyes. If I don't write about my OCs I feel like I'm going to die while being around friends or makes me feel more unfulfilled. It's most likely because I am over privileged so I find life and socializing boring because boredom in itself is a luxury.

posts.com:
Long version of "just draw":
I believe art with the most creativity are ones created in the moment.
People obsessed with practicing the fundamentals and not their imagination/spontaneity create generic art, no matter how good it may look.
They don't know how to have fun with their art, and are too afraid to present the crude/janky shit everyone makes on their way to greatness.
Just own your art, no matter how cringe or bad it is. You'll look back at it later and compare it to your current stuff, and smile.
You know, unless you stagnate/get worse for some reason.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6367918
Depends on the colors and obviously on the pigment, let's just say that even on artist grade gouache they're very liberal with their lightfastness grading. Traditional gouache was never meant to be archival, it doesn't form a film once it dries, it's chalky and gets dirty fast unless you put it under glass, it's was meant for illustrators to quickly turn their artwork, photograph it for publishing and forget about it.
General speaking you should worry about the pinks but there are colors that people not suspect like raw sienna and yellow ochre, they will get grayer, unless you use W&N brand which has better pigments than other brands.
Even acrylic will shift, I have Golden Fluid Yellow Ochre and it shifted to gray months later. Any color that looks saturated and vibrant won't stay that way for long.

>>6367918
>Is artist grade Gouache worth it?
Yes. You'll get more pigment, smoother grind, better flow, single-pigment colours (better mixing), less fillers (more vibrant). Schmincke is great, and I can wholly recommend. Just get a few tubes of artist-grade instead of a bunch of chinesium.

>I also want to start painting with acrylic. Do it need any special medium like oil paint or just apply directly on canvas?
Water-soluble, so thinning with water works. You'll only need mediums if you want to thin it a ton, since super-thinned paint films are not necessarily durable. Other than that you can pretty much paint on anything. It's essentially coloured plastic.

There's like a million mediums that you won't need but that could be nice, like thickeners, thinners, drying time extenders, crackling, more shine, less shine, flow improvers, etc. You can make a frankenpaint to your specific liking if you really want to tinker with it.

>>6368450
As said in last thread, Mont Marte probably does not manufacture their own stuff and commission random (see: cheapest) manufacturer to make stuff they just repackage. Sometimes you can get decent stuff, but it really is playing art supply gacha.

HIMI Jelly Gouache is significantly better, and honestly a pretty decent quality paint. I would recommend Holbein, if that's available in your neck of the woods.

>>6368722
>unless you use W&N brand which has better pigments than other brands.
Holbein, WN, Schmincke Horadam, and M. Graham all make Gouache without the addition of whiteners, relying on pure pigment density to get opacity. Any of these will work. It's notable that Holbein is by far the cheapest, at least in EU, and Schmincke pigment is very finely ground so it's less opaque than the others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6372118
chalk/marble dust (can extend pigments in oil; use for making paint transparent for glazing in oil; traditional glue chalk ground is less expensive than ready-made acrylic ground and dry components store longer; use as opacifier in gouache)
rabbit skin glue/hide glue (used for grounds, sizing; distemper medium; glue for attaching canvas to board)
metal point (small piece lasts very long; brass can be found for free, or buy/find wire that lasts many life times over; some can fit into a clutch pencil; can coat scrap wood with chalk and or some other ground of your choice in weak glue size and reuse board for scrap drawings, by recoating or scraping)
charcoal powder (can be made for free; decent for ink with suitable binder ground finely; good for paint; use for tracing; many other uses)
egg (yolk and pigment for egg tempera, good for lean underpainting for oil paint or as a cheap and durable paint, don't need entire yolk; can make water-miscible paint by adding to oil paint, thin and clean with water instead of solvents; glair, made by whipping egg white and letting liquid separate from foam, can be used as paint or ink binder; adjust strength with distilled water; can be dried by pouring in a shallow container and letting sit, dissolve again by water; supposedly aged wet, not too tightly sealed glair is better; can be modified by adding honey or sugar etc; used in some varnish recipes; can be use in metal point grounds)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6372834
None if you use inks, if not then the film isn't strong enough to adhere to the other layers, should be fine if you're just staining the paper. Use gesso, it will create blooms like watercolor.

Too much water will upset the balance and spread the acrylic polymer too thinly so the molecules can't reconnect properly to form a stable film. Instead you should dilute with an acrylic medium, which is essentially the same as the paint but without the color pigment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6375078
if lead is only a trace element in zinc, imagine how little is in titanium wtth 2-5% zinc. painting with cadmium colors is so much more dangerous at that point.
there's a number of inert pigments that are mostly transparent in the average layer of oil paint you can add to make any pigment more transparent.
calcium carbonate (chalk, egg shells, marble, limestone), silica (crushed glass, pumice, silica-rich sand, quartz). calcium carbonate is safer because silica can damage lungs much more. make a paint mixing the transparent pigment with oil to a consistency you like and add it to your tube paint, or add chalk directly and add oil if it is too lean.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6375089
>By the way, just HOW dangerous is Lead white if you don't grind it yourself? For example are you in trouble if you get it on your skin while painting?
Not in quantities you'd use if it happens a couple of times, but over time you could get yourself in trouble. Lead doesn't really leave your body basically ever once it gets in. By itself, anyway: you can get rid of most of it with Dimercaprol.

If you get it in your food somehow, either by having it in your fingers (Even if it's so little as to not show clearly) or clothes or whatever, that's actually bad. That's why it's recommended to use gloves (Nitrile only: Latex can get dissolved by oil/solvents) and to never eat/drink while in the studio if working with lead white.

Mostly it's a case of "better safe than sorry", but there's genuine long-term health risks that many underestimate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Whats the difference between using linseed oil vs paint thinner for thinning oil paints?
Everything I can find online seems to talk about them interchangeably, is there a reason to use one over the other?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6390809
+linseed oil makes the paint have more oil (oil to pigment ratio increases) slower drying, more gloss, not as easy to paint over dry, harder for atmospheric vapors and moisture to penetrate, more yellowing, more flexible, used for glazes
+paint thinner makes makes the oil thinner (oil to pigment ratio remains the same but effectively lower since it also breaks down oil) leaner and thinner paint layer, more matte surface, pigment can be unbound if thinned too much, more susceptible to dirt and moisture penetration due to microscopic pores, faster drying, mostly used for under layers

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6399981
Brushes and brush pens can be a bit difficult to get used to since you feel much less contact with the surface, but they're a lot of fun. Definitely the most versatile mark-making wise, but it takes a bit of practice to be able to do very fine detail work with them.
Pic related is great since you can control how much ink is loaded on it for drybrush effects and stuff, unlike the Pentel Pocket Brush which is always wet (which makes it a bit more difficult to handle, too).
Dip pens aren't bad choices either, but they also take some getting used to. Just wanted to mention brushes since I feel like they're a bit overlooked these days which is a shame.
Waterproof ink gives brushes a shorter lifespan, but it's not that big of a deal. Pen nibs break and brushes eventually lose their point, but you'll still probably go through them much slower than fineliners.

to clarify
i wasn't talking about watercolor. i meant that even for drawings in dry media i only use pure cotton paper, (but not watercolor cotton paper.) if you explain to buyers of watercolor that something is made of cotton, that's simply expected, especially if the buyer has been in the market for buying watercolor works.
i go beyond what is expected when it comes to materials. for oil painting, the standard is simply to use tube paints, with titanium as the white, over acrylic gesso. i grind from dry pigments, use the best lead white available, and use lead oil ground with the same lead white.
it's not merely an issue of the work fading or deteriorating in 10 years or in their lifetime either. as there are practices and materials that i admit are more archival, but are simply not as beautiful, prestigious, or expensive. aluminum panels, mdf, and plywood are very stable, but are not as inspiring as a joined solid wood panel with hand cut butterfly keys. when it comes to works of art, i consider the support as part of the art, so they must be beautiful as well.
or some materials might outlast others in a few hundred years, but the more available materials are good enough.

posts.com:
>>6415758
there are illustrations of both in use or separately.
palette is good for mixing various tones and making the range of movement more efficient in painting. it also means the paint is somewhat more paste-like. mixtures from the paste can be thinned down with water or more medium, or painted dry thinly. i notice that palettes were generally smaller, because the mixes were simpler and they painted differently colored parts separately, and that the familiar kidney shaped palette became more common later.
shells and bowls are good for fluid paints. the ribs of the shells or the rim of the bowl makes it easy to remove excess moisture from the brush. the bowl shape also means that moisture evaporates slower. one can make different mixes in separate shells but this can be wasteful since you often only need a small amount of each especially since tempera is painted very thinly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6415075

The sets are bad, you're paying a lot for hues that don't play well together.

Only get the SKETCH markers, not the Classic or Ciao. Start with a cool/neutral/warm gray set depending on your style and needs, they can be used as a base with other hues.

Then buy a set of singles with similar color intensities and ID's. Check this guide to make sense of the ID system: https://markernovice.com/copic/copic-numbering

If you're going for realism you're not going to want all the intense candy shades, plus that the hue samples usually look lighter than they'll end up on your paper/pad after several strokes, and a lot of the really lighter shades (X000 etc) can be used to mix with other hues for great effect.

So for a range of blues you might want B21 Baby Blue, B91 Night Blue, B37 Antwerp Blue, B61 Light Hydrangea, instead of the intense ones like B29 Ultramarine, B16 Caynine Blue or B06 Peacock Blue. You can easily get by with a set of 3-4 in each hue range, some skintones, some ultralights, which might amount to 20 or so markers total. A lot cheaper than 72 goofball hues that don't blend well.

You'll get a blender with a gray set but it's not what you think, blending is done by carefully connecting two adjacent hues and not with the blender marker, it's more of an FX thing that'll wet your strokes and turn them abit watercolory.

My favorite surface is fine Carrara marble dust that is mixed with Dutch lead white which has been ground in vinegar and washed, sometimes tinted with other pigments. For darker lines, some pumice or quartz. For the glue, I choose parchment size mixed with a solution of potash alum.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428703
I can't see any of those videos, only the thumbnails because I don't have an Instagram account, but it looks like he uses a fair bit of line weight.
Fineliners are alright and very straightforward for a beginner to use since they always have a single constant width but they won't get you natural line variation, you'll need to manually thicken the line by drawing over it. Their lines can feel very mechanical otherwise, which is only natural considering they're like a disposable version of technical drawing pens.
Fineliners don't shatter under your hand or anything, but they tend to be inconsistent and start having ink flow problems with time, requiring you to hold them very vertically to keep working. The problem is compounded if you happen to be heavy-handed, so if you think that might end up a problem it might be a good idea to pick up Uni-pins instead since they have very durable tips.
But Microns are perfectly well-loved pens as far as their type goes. If you're in for even and consistent lines it's what fineliners will give you.

posts.name: Anonymous

ty anon, im still a little confused and looking for direction.

I just wanna try doing some manga style with dynamic line weight, whats a good starting point in terms of pens for learning anime/manga

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428775
Mangaka mainly use dip pens (pic rel), but they're difficult to control and can be a bit hard to find. Bristle brush pens and proper brushes have the most line variation and they're what's behind most of those 熱血 crazy-looking thick lines in drawings by animators like Umakoshi and Hayama. They're also very difficult to control. The difficulty can be a good thing if you want to challenge yourself and train your dexterity, but it could get frustrating for a beginner.
Felt tip brush pens are comparatively really easy to control and you can still get good line variety out of them. I've never used the Micron one but it's probably fine.
A lot of manga artists do use fineliners, but it's usually for details, hatching or speech bubbles. Maru nibs produce similarly thin lines, but they can thicken a bit if you press harder. You can still get super delicate lines out of a pen or brush if you're skilled enough, Akihito Yoshitomi does a lot of detailed machine drawings with dip pens on YouTube if you're interested in watching someone ink in real time.
That's not to say nobody ever inks mainly with fineliners, and I think they were common in shoujo manga in the 2000s. They're very popular with people who draw anime-style illustrations on social media and can be very convenient to work with. They eventually worm their way into a lot of people's workflows, so there's no harm getting some experience with them now if you want to. I think with inking it's definitely a matter of trying a lot of things and seeing what suits you.
Whatever you end up with, I hope you have fun, Anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6447254
Honestly go for the one that appeals most to you. If price is a big factor any medium works well with a limited palette of 6 or more colors. There are many ways to make a certain medium more expensive and cheap, which is why I would also consider oil. For example, oil paint covers huge areas easily with very little paint and there are inexpensive oil painting papers to paint on. Another example is if you compare gouache and watercolor, the gouache paint is a little bit more expensive, because you will finish it faster, but on the other hand, you don't need good paper for gouache. All of them have their difficulties and advantages, but if I would recommend an all rounder that's forgiving I would suggest oil even though it's not in your list. If this is not an option for you, I would choose gouache over acrylic, because it's forgiving in brush quality and maintanence and it's better for sketching and making smaller pieces. The emulsion is not as strong as with acrylic, which makes it easier to handle the paint on the brush and canvas. Go for watercolor only if you love watercolor or you going to have a bad time. Watercolor is an outlier and has some specific qualities that you only should put up with if you really want to go for the watercolor look and feel. I agree that it's inexpensive to get into though, but it benefits from higher quality paper. So all in all, I would suggest gouache if you don't want to consider oil, but personally I don't like the Himi gouache, it has a strange consistency and it has too many colors. Consider a high quality brand like W&N, Holbein, Schmincke, Graham, but getting a small limited palette of 5-7 colors plus a big tube of white. Get those air tight wet palettes that everyone uses for gouache nowadays (I use them too, they are great) and you are good to go with a couple of synthetic taklon brushes. While you need thick paper to prevent buckling, you don't need 100% cotton, gouache is fine on cheap, thicker paper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
on the subject of least expensive medium
technically, it would be using dry pigments mixed with gum arabic or egg yolk.
egg tempera is cheaper if you take a bit of the yolk from when you cook with eggs. a whole yolk is too much waste.
gum arabic is cheaper when you consider a bag of the dry powder can last for years upon years.
extra expenses are that egg tempera should be done on stiff support that is covered with traditional gesso ground which can be intimidating for a lot of beginners. i have tricks for anyone who actually cares to use it. watercolor paper can be more expensive if you don't have access to scrap wood. but if you don't egg or gum paint, then you can try out other media with the pigments.
for both, kolinsky is considered the best which can be quite expensive. but great thing for either is that they are not hard on the brushes unlike how oil can be and especially acrylic, and brush clean up is easier.

posts.com: Is there any quality difference in disposable vs reusable technical pens like Sakura Microns vs Rapidographs?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6455419
I'm not a Micron fan. I do like that they're readily available even in stores like Walmart in case you need an emergency art pen, but otherwise that's their only pro in my opinion.

I use both the reusable Copic pens and the disposable. The reusable ones are way more expensive up front but quickly pay for themselves, so I buy the pens I use the most in refillable form and everything else is disposable. Quality-wise, they're both pretty much the same so I wouldn't recommend shelling out for the refillable kind if you're just using them every once in a while or you (understandably) don't want to spend like $12 on a pen. The other type of pen I use is a G pen, which is both affordable and uses affordable dipping ink that last forever. My only complaint there is that it's not as convenient as the non-dip pens and also the ink takes a while to dry sometimes. I have never used Rapidographs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Do you really get better from "just drawing"? I could probably do that everyday but I don't think it'll help. It's the studying/mental effort that makes drawing difficult for me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6445952
Yes and no. You won’t magically learn new skills by just drawing. But you’ll build up many of the required prerequisites to drawing like hand eye coordination, focus, understanding of the process, visual recognition, etc…
Theyre the time consuming skills that you can’t be taught by reading a book. And until you actually put in the physical time drawing and gain those skill you’ll be dogshit no matter how much you study or however many books you read.

Just drawing is an absolute necessity to gitting gud and it will improve your baseline abilities. But it won’t reach you new concepts by itself until you bother learning them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6452542
>Spent 5 years of my life trying to get better
How much of this was dedicated practice or at the very least just drawing.

>Then realized I didn't have the talent to Finally Make that Comic
You don't need talent to make a comic , but your talent will determine how good the comic looks. You could start right now , seeing "that comic" get better will hopefully will give you the motivation to improve.

>psychologically hemhorraging my acquired skills for amny reasons both within and from out of my control.
Feel ya.
TL:DR Draw that comic , doesn't matter how bad you are , you will always set the bar higher and it will never be "good enough".

>More and more it feels like a herculean effort to draw shit that was so intuitive to draw and provided me so much joy before
Might be because one or more of the following:
1) Fried dopamine receptors - If nothing else is enjoyable in general , this is it.
2) You got rusty - Uou have not drawn in a while and your brain has to remember things you used to be second nature. This will take much less time than learning it for the first time. This should not take long.
3) You turned art into a chore - Instead of art being something you like to do , it has become something you MUST do for one reason or another and that isn't because you like it so much you MUST do it , it has become an obligation. Be it because you consider it productive and productivity is the end all be all. Because you want to get better and once you get better (whenever that is) you will finally be able to draw that comic , because you are afraid NGMI ,etc..
4) Likely not your case in this scenario but could be hobby burnout , you drew too much and pushed yourself too far (can even happen without realising it , happened to me once)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6452542
>I hope the regret really hits me at some point for deciding to be a lazy fuck.
Based on this post it appears to have hit you already , and if not , it is deffnetly on it's way so... don't make it worse.
At the very least cut out the scrolling and video games (videogames are fine in moderation but you seem to be using them as a way to avoid doing difficult things instead of harmless fun)

>I dont deserve to be happy
Define "deserve" , what should one do to or more specifcally , what should you do to "deserve" to be happy. Even if you do not deserve it, its in your intrest to strive towards happiness.

>let alone exist.
That is a bit too much , it's not like you tortured someone then brutally murdered them for fun. You just got addicted to stuff that was engineered from the bottom up to get you to use it and then to get addicted to it, a trap specifically made to catch humans like you or me (by other humans).

>I only feel bitter and resentful when i see the people who were so good at drawing the things i drew and did it with no effort whatsoever that it broke my mind and i just gave up.

I would personally try to see what they did/what they are doing and what I do myself to get to their level.
They can do things with no effort that you struggle with because they simply have more knowledge, experience , dedicated practice or even just time messing around and having fun with it. With time and effort , you will get to their level.

>TLDR dont use social media
Excessive scrolling can deffinetly fuck you up.
My TL:DR is:
-Draw that comic you always wanted to (no matter your current skill level , even if you are stickman level)
-Figure out what has made drawing so unenjoyable and try to make it fun again. (eg. Turning a WANT into a MUST)
-Your instinctual reaction to difficulty should not be reaching for a dopamine hit that wont get shit done
-Learn from those who are better than you (a growth mindset might help , you may have a fixed mindset)

Instead of taking a course, do the following every day for a week:

Write down a list of at least 5 things you like. Does not have to be only artists, can be media of any sort, or hell even odd shit like food if you want.

Make a venn diagram. Label it with one of the 5 subjects.
Write what you want to learn from the subject, artwise, in the middle
Write what you already can do as good or better than the subject in the left
Write what you don't like/care about the subject in the right.

Repeat for each of the daily 5.

---

It's an exercise for self-awareness and understanding your influences and where you want your directions to go. When you have done all these you can then use that knowledge to know what you wanna study from the different subjects. Character design is downstream from that stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6446839
Here's the way the site works: when you try to load a video, the website launches an app on your computer for the video player. This is a proprietary player you need to install AND must be running at all times, otherwise the video stops playing. This software, while running (even if the site is closed), straight up blocks any kind of capture, even simple screenshots, which is annoying if you want to copy the photo the instructor is using as a ref, since they are generally not provided in the exercise files. On top of all that, the website puts your full name + user ID randomly somewhere on the screen over the video. It's not always there, pops in and out, and is on a random area of the video every time.

In short, there ARE a few ways to record the screen and get the video and bypass their player cockblocking you, but you'll still have a tiny watermark with your personal info randomly teleporting over the screen, which you'd have to manually cover in video editing, a pain in the ass, and also might end up blocking useful areas of the video, so it's really not worth it unless someone develops an addon to scrape the video directly off the site before the watermark is overlaid on top, and then somehow either also obtain the subtitles, or recreate them from scratch.

>>6452265
There is literally nothing avant-garde in the image you posted. It's shit that everyone has seen a million times before and the reason that it doesn't pull any attention outside of druggie circles is that there's really nothing deep or innovative about it after the first time around. The thing that a lot of cookie-cutter "creative" types fail to understand is that you can't achieve depth only from dwelling at length on an emotion or a sentiment or a surface-level notion of what is "significant"; nor from focusing exclusively on the craft of conveyance without developing a critical eye for what is worthy to be conveyed. You need quality and breadth of learning and experience in order to develop the discernment to know which topics are genuinely avant-garde and which are rightfully beneath the contempt of even the most glassy-eyed bydlo. It's a simple matter of combinatorial complexity—no matter how strongly you may feel about something or how adroitly you may symbolise it, a single word, image, or concept encodes very little information (therefore value) on its own. Complexity, nuance, comes from the multiplicity and multifarity of its associations with other words, images, and concepts; and especially from the wealth of accumulated such associations to be found within the collective human oeuvre.

Drugs are not a shortcut because all they fundamentally do is permute what is already in your brain in slightly novel ways, whilst amplifying the emotional significance of them entirely out of proportion with their actual merit. If you had nothing of worth in there before, then that is also what you will have afterwards; except you will be falsely and intensely convinced of otherwise. Why do you think the basic druggie stereotype is of a perpetually self-impressed idiot? Only with a well-developed conceptual library can altered states of mind precipitate genuine innovation.
